conclusion: Objects A and B are in the air above the surface where objects C, D, E, and F are located. Gravity is acting on all objects, pulling them downwards.
Objects A and B are moved downwards through the air, towards the surface, under the influence of gravity.

Object A is directed towards the area where objects C and D are located (near the red fabric). Object B is directed towards the area where objects E and F are located (near the patterned fabric, where E and F are stacked).
As A and B descend, gravity pulls them down until they encounter a physical barrier, which is either the surface or one or more of the objects C, D, E, or F.

Upon contact, A will come to rest, supported by whatever it landed on, which could be the surface, object C or D, or a combination. Similarly, B will come to rest, supported by whatever it landed on, which could be the surface, object E, or object F.

At the point of contact, A will exert a downward force on the object(s) or surface supporting it, and the supporting object(s) or surface will exert an equal and opposite upward normal force on A. The same applies to object B and its supporting object(s) or surface.

When objects A and B are placed down at the location of objects C, D, E, and F, gravity pulls A downwards until it makes contact with the surface or objects C and D. A will then come to rest, supported by the surface and/or C and D, exerting its weight upon them while they provide an upward supporting force. Similarly, gravity pulls B downwards until it makes contact with the surface or objects E and F. B will then come to rest, supported by the surface and/or E and F, exerting its weight upon them while they provide an upward supporting force.
